text: right here right now
I must confess something to you all I
shouldn't be here
truly not in the figurative humblebrag
my GMAT wasn't perfect or I can only
speak three languages or I only went to
Yale kind of way but very literally I
should not be here not at this
institution nothing about my background
or ambitions spoke to a Harvard Business
School pedigree having worked at the
University of Phoenix subject of not one
but two cases during the RC year and
what of many jokes during my entire
duration Thank You HBS show all
seemingly implying that I specifically
have been boozled all of America
surely this didn't fit into the HBS idea
or even in my Silicon Valley startup
instead of choosing the more traditional
tech based approach I chose to pursue my
passion for food and created a jam and
preserves manufacturing company before
Silicon Valley there was my brief stint
working at a bank at UBS in London now
surely this would be the time where I
would solidify my b-school legitimacy
even in the seemingly congruent action I
found dissonance having started right
before the financial crisis in 2007
turns out that market timing isn't my
strongest suit before the bank I worked
at General Mills not within its hallowed
brand management group but within the
sales division
I carved out this professional path of
near misses and detours that never
seemed to add up to what I thought was
the distinction of a typical HBS student
but these are just my professional
memories to fully understand we must go
back further back back towards the
beginning of what shapes me HBS was also
a mismatch of my personal identity as a
bohemian idealist who cares more about
preserving nectarines and Meyer lemons
than a balance sheet I couldn't see how
the school would fit into my value
system as a woman of color southerner
and lesbian simply put I had no concept
of but what it meant to be a boardroom
leader as there were so few of them that
seemed to embody all of Who I am even
the mere act of applying was a fight the
only reason why I chose to apply was one
of my mentors and HBS alum mind you
forced me to on condition of writing my
recommendation for a different school
that I had chosen but finally sold me on
applying to HBS was one of his
ubiquitous Wayne Gretzky quotes he's a
Canadian so I guess they teach them to
you from birth he told me Adi you miss
100% of the shots you don't take
he got me cut to my core sense of
competitiveness having no recourse but
to accept his challenge I put in my
application so now I'm here
but I didn't miraculously find my path
once I landed in Boston in my mind I was
still the different one and I came with
a big old bag of being different being
the only black lesbian on campus for my
entire two-year tenure
and D if you are listening I hope you
have someone in the pipeline because
this is it even being a more experienced
candidate having worked for over a
decade prior to application
it was tough feeling out of place from
the start not knowing what I would find
so here I am at Harvard with this
seemingly uncompelled abide and after
the first day on campus I still felt
different day to much the same but
grudgingly I found some solace in this
section experience to help overcome the
sense of alienation
I was shocked how easy it was to succumb
to the beauty of having so many
different opinions brought into the
classroom in appreciating that while we
may have many different perspectives no
one singular voice held the answer the
feeling of alienation began to dissipate
once I started seeing this environment
for what it really is a collection of
differences everyone brought their own
bag with them it's just our luggage all
looked a little different the section
experience forces us to confront our
differences in the classroom but this
confrontation doesn't only happen in the
classroom it doesn't only happen in
one-on-one meetings with professors or
in review sessions it happens in the
cracks in all the ephemeral intangible
moments the small group dinners the
impromptu conversations in between
classes for me the moment that was most
pivot pivotal for exemplifying this was
my presentation for National Coming Out
Day to my section I had so much fear and
angst and the lead-up to this discussion
what if I lose friends within section
because of Who I am what if I offend
someone what if no one shows up what if
I bare my soul and no one cares
much to my relief I found quite a
different reaction because I was so
willing to share something so essential
to Who I am
others in my section now felt
comfortable sharing their stories and
struggles my story was just one in a
litany of how our lives beliefs shaped
who we are collectively these two years
have been a journey towards
understanding what makes us unique these
differences can come in many different
shapes and forms for some it may be the
mere act of engaging in the case method
when English is not your first language
for others it may be a more personal
challenge such as difficult
relationships with your family or
feeling like you need to live up to
someone else's expectations it could
even be the fear that you are the only
one who has no idea on who or what you
want to become in this world these are
all valid experiences unique to each and
every one of us and it is this
incredible diversity that becomes the
real personal growth that we achieve
here it's not enough for us to just be
different it is this close vulnerable
place we put ourselves in that makes
this experience rich it is this
collective tissue of connective truths
and personal stories and ideologies that
create something new a new body a new
spirit a new sense of purpose that
pushes us further because richer
experiences make us better they enable
us to see the world from multiple
perspectives and think deeper on how to
improve it they provide us with a new
lens in which to see the world thus we
can see clearly what we couldn't have
seen
they make us better because they help us
make our world better so with this I
have another confession I was wrong as
much as I wanted to believe that I
shouldn't be here this is exactly where
I need it to be this experience this
push out of my comfort zone academically
this challenge of building community
with so many different people was the
necessary discomfort to push me towards
this incredibly rich and utterly
stunning life I could nor had not
imagined even in this moment standing in
front of you here has been exactly the
push to avoid my comfort zone that I
need preparing and giving the speech has
been a process a very scary nerve
wracking most days I wish I hadn't
volunteered but necessary process in
spite of the discomfort I've relished
this process because in it holds the key
to my own transformation it is this
constant challenge that Spurs renewal
and ultimately makes me a better person
a person who dares to speak here and a
person who seeks to continue learning
from differences now that we all can
acknowledge our differences and see that
they are what improve our lives we must
take the next step we must use this
experience to transform our environment
now that we have built this new body new
spirit new lens in which to see the
world we must keep it for in the words
of Aristotle we are what we continually
do excellence then is not an act but a
habit the privilege of having learned in
this experience thus becomes our
obligation to bring this to the world
more importantly
we should be different after we leave my
differences aren't erased once I leave
here furthermore this school should have
produced the same type of leaders 50
years ago I wouldn't be on the stage
worse yet I wouldn't even be at the
school thank goodness HBS changed it had
to in order to adapt to the shift in
social environment of business climate
the makeup of the student body had to
transform and it must continue this
shift in order to progress against
obsolescence it must continue to answer
the question of what it means to build
leaders who embrace differences and
thrive in unchartered environments we
all need to be intentional and how
changed we become from this the world
will continue to evolve and thus our
ability to fit in it will be a con going
work-in-progress we all will get the
same degree tomorrow but that's where
our sameness ends we should all be the
same but rather challenge our own view
of the world with our own unique
perspectives moreover our voice as
leaders must speak to this eclectic and
ever-changing environment and adapt as
necessary
as for me I'm moving to a new city in a
new country taking on a new job at a new
company I'm building this constellation
of newness upon graduation it's daunting
but it's also thrilling and it's the
best way I know to challenge myself to
embody the mission of HBS and my own
value system as I look to you all I ask
that you take this challenge
again it is not enough for us to just be
different
further it's not enough for us to just
get out of our comfort zone as we all go
beyond HBS into the next phase of our
life whether that's in a new city in a
civilian career after military service
whether that's in a new industry
creating your own company or even going
back to the same company you worked at
previously we must continue the pursuit
towards understanding the unfamiliar now
that we have accepted the privilege of
this experience we must seek out
differences seek out ways to challenge
ourselves and others seek out new cracks
and new intangible moments make a career
of humanity that embraces differences
for you will make a greater person of
yourself a greater nation of your
country in a finer world to live in
thank you very much
